text: dedicated followers of fashion will
recognize Tom Brown as the designer who
introduced a new streamlined shape to
menswear a few years back he's known for
shaking up the status quo with his
distinctive updates on traditional
American sportswear
as a wetsuit for that formal surfing day
you're taking a very you know basic idea
and really just showing it to people in
a way that they may not have seen and I
think that's important for us to do some
of the ideas that I that I introduced
aren't so masculine sometimes so it's
nice to balance it off with something
that may be more familiar to to a guy
each season mr. Brown typically explores
a sports theme such as skiing or surfing
for this season tennis I call it the
officer's jacket so it has the look of
the flared autumn of a classic officer's
jacket but with the detail of the very
women's inspired tool I think guys are
braver than they have been I think
they're dressing more than they have I
don't think it's as casual as it used to
be there will always be a gray suit in
my collections so I'd like to introduce
you know new ideas that make that gray
suit even more interesting
whether or not you like his ideas mr.
Brown's narrower boyish cuts have had an
enormous impact on the broader menswear
market where it is now common to find
prep school Blazers and grosgrain
trimmed cuffs even on the clothes @j
crew and Club Monaco for me as a
designer I like to actually show
different things and I like to entertain
and I like people to have a good time I
like people because I know not everyone
you know will love everything that I'm
doing but I I want them to at least
appreciate the experience of what they
get to see at the show
mr. Brown's collection was nearly
complete last week so he was busy
considering how things would go together
and in what order for the show one
season he presented his clothes on an
indoor skating rink another it was at a
circus complete with a three-legged
pantsuit and a model on stilts but the
themes act merely as a framework for his
continuing play on the classical ideas
of men's clothing always centered on his
ultimate mode chief of tradition the
tailored grey suit it's interesting to
see how his designs change each season
in ways that are sometimes subtle and
sometimes outrageous
